snippet: When Harvard alums talk about the Red Book, they’re not talking about Mao Zedong’s pamphlet of axioms, but a compilation of dispatches from graduates sharing accounts of their lives since finishing college.
abstract: Deborah Copaken Kogan novel The Red Book chronicles the 20th reunion of four roommates from Harvard University's class of 1989; work is based on the university's famed Red Book, a reunion report issued to Harvard graduates every five years that contains hundreds of pages of dispatches sent in by alumni.
lead_paragraph: When Harvard alums talk about the Red Book, they’re not talking about Mao Zedong’s pamphlet of axioms, but a compilation of dispatches from graduates sharing accounts of their lives since finishing college.

headline.main: Between the Lines of Harvard’s Red Book
headline.print_headline: Between the Lines Of Harvard’s Red Book
